data.title: No_JNI found at box2d.so and freetype.so
Intersector distanceLinePoint vs distanceSegmentPoint
data.body:
Hi, in file Intersector.java, there are two methods with similar functionalities (at least by comments) but with different implementations. Is this by design?

```
/** Returns the distance between the given line segment and point.
 * 
 * @param start The line start point
 * @param end The line end point
 * @param point The point
 * 
 * @return The distance between the line segment and the point. */
public static float distanceLinePoint (Vector2 start, Vector2 end, Vector2 point)
```

and

```
/** Returns the distance between the given segment and point. */
public static float distanceSegmentPoint (Vector2 start, Vector2 end, Vector2 point) 
```

(and the corresponding `float` version).

The `distanceLinePoint` method is a bit confusing, since the name suggests it uses lines instead of line segments, and there is an overload with `float`s instead of `Vector2`s which doesn't take line segments but lines instead.

data.title: Consider making libgdx configurable for what RoboVM backend version to use
data.body: Currently the libGDX ant build always pulls the latest RoboVM backend jars, which can cause problems when there are API-breaking changes to RoboVM that are not in the version of libGDX you are building. Commenting out the fetch roboVM part of build.xml is a workaround, but this could probably be handled differently.

data.title: TiledMap with different tile sizes
data.body:
I was eager to write some detailed bug report, but I got the feeling I may be doing something wrong here. I'm trying to render a `.tmx` tiled map using `TmxLoader` and `OrthogonalTiledMapRenderer`. The gist of it is that the width and height defined in my map _do not_ coincide with those of the tiles. So, in my `.tmx` file I have something like the following:

```
<map version="1.0" orientation="orthogonal" width="21" height="10" tilewidth="35" tileheight="35">
 <tileset firstgid="1" name="tiles" tilewidth="70" tileheight="70" spacing="2" margin="2">
  <image source="tiles.png" width="1874" height="434"/>
 </tileset>
...
```

`tilewidth` and `tileheight` in `<map>` are half of what they are in `<tileset>`. That way, every texture region is 2x2 tiles in size.

With that setup, tiles are rendered ok, but **when the camera is moving to the right**, some unexpected gaps appear on every tile that leaves, or is about to leave, the screen. Like so:

![tile-gap](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/476069/4382677/06fc3262-438f-11e4-850f-33b0ae4b75ba.png)

Though I'm not entirely sure, this doesn't seem to be related to _texture bleeding_, which is also happening in my scenario (haven't corrected it, yet).

I have already tried different spritesheet arrangements using `TexturePacker2` and [CodeAndWeb's TexturePacker](https://www.codeandweb.com/texturepacker) (like inner padding, edge padding, extrude, square sizes, etc.), but no no avail. Also, this **does not occur if I create a new map with`tilewidth` and `tileheight` being the same as my tileset**. The very same spritesheet works as expected.

So, is there something I'm missing? Perhaps, some rounding errors related to the camera?  Is this even supported by the renderers in _libGDX_?

data.title: Actor.setPosition with alignment
data.body:
Recent changes by @NathanSweet removed the method setCenterPosition and replaced it by an extended setPosition method which may except alignment as parameter.

When using Align.center as alignment I'd expect the actor to be centered to the given coordinates. Instead, what happens is that the actor is offset by half the size in the wrong direction, i.e. instead of
`x = x - width/2`
the formula 
`x = x + width/2`
is used. I can't think of any scenario where this might be useful. Is this really the intended purpose?

data.title: JsonReader fails to parse comments after 1.0.0.
data.body:
#### Usecase:

**Input:**

``` java
JsonValue value1 = new JsonReader().parse("// Just a comment \n {foo: bar}");
System.out.println(value1);
```

**Output:**
###### libgdx 1.0.0

``` json
{
foo: bar
}
```
###### libgdx 1.0.1

``` java
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SerializationException: Error parsing JSON on line 1 near: Just a comment 
 {foo: bar}
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.JsonReader.parse(JsonReader.java:468)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.JsonReader.parse(JsonReader.java:38)
    at com.randombot.theme.SkinPacker.create(SkinPacker.java:26)

    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication$1.run(LwjglApplication.java:114)
```
###### libgdx 1.3.1 and leatest nightly

``` java
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.SerializationException: Error parsing JSON on line 1 near: Just a comment 
 {foo: bar}
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.JsonReader.parse(JsonReader.java:471)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.utils.JsonReader.parse(JsonReader.java:38)
    at com.randombot.theme.SkinPacker.create(SkinPacker.java:26)
```

I think the commit that added this behavior was this one: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/d57d1850d9aca8f7148dad3189e1039f8027b3dc

I assumed this isn't the desired behavior after seeing this line: https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/d57d1850d9aca8f7148dad3189e1039f8027b3dc/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/utils/JsonReader.rl#L228 .

data.title: LibGDX doesn't scale properly on iPhone 6+ or iPhone 6 in zoomed mode
data.body:
in IOSGraphics.java, the code only handles device scale == 2. Since the 6+ has scale of 3, games are shrunk to a corner of the screen in the 6+. We need to modify this to simply multiply by the scale in all cases.

There is also a perhaps more subtle bug on the iPhone 6 in "zoomed" mode. In a similar way, the game is restricted to a corner of the screen. Not exactly sure here what the fix is, still diagnosing it.
